title: Using this package
text: manuscript presents open data product {TTS2016R}. Open data products result turning source data (open otherwise) accessible information adds value original inputs (see Arribas-Bel et al. 2021). product presented paper R data package currently consists three objects sourced 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) curated facilitate use analysis TTS data. package includes person--jobs origin-destinations, traffic analysis zone (TAZ) boundaries, planning/municipality boundaries Greater Golden Horse area (GGH) located southern Ontario, Canada (Data Management Group 2018). addition, package includes TAZ centroid--centroid travel times car computed using package {r5r} (Pereira et al. 2021). aim paper walk readers empirical home-based work commute data set, illustrate calculation impedance function, showcase can used calculate accessibility employment, invite use applications. Data TTS principle available public fully open, since permission access data retrieval system required. addition, raw data can technically demanding, cumbersome work , requires multiple software process. pre-processing data R environment, {TTS2016R} offers slice TTS data useful understand patterns commuting work region. also provides open infrastructure additional TTS complimentary data sets amended authors wider open-source community future.

title: Using this package
text: {TTS2016R} includes counts fully-employed population place residence counts full-time jobs place work aggregated TAZ (n=3,764 within survey boundaries). Unique identifiers use GTA06 Zoning System TTS. number jobs (3,081,900) workers (3,446,957) organized form origin-destination table, indicative patterns home--work commute (3,446,957 potential interactions). data retrieved Transportation Tomorrow Survey Data Retrieval System October 28, 2021 reflect potential interaction full-time employed people jobs within GGH survey boundaries shown Figure  defined 2016 TTS methodology (Data Management Group 2018). Also included {TTS2016R} travel times cost travel origin destination car; travel times calculated using R package {r5r}. travel times useful estimate cost travel calculate impedance functions, among possible uses. important note simplicity, interactions within {TTS2016R} assumed taken car, travel time calculated origin TAZ centroid destination TAZ centroid. centroid snapped nearest street line r5r travel time calculated trips assuming car travel mode. Additionally, travel times less equal 180 mins (3 hrs) calculated; threshold represents 99% trip’s travel times summarized descriptive statistics Table . TTS 2016 study area within Greater Golden Horseshoe Ontario, Canada.
code: #forming a complete descriptive statistic table  Statistics <- data.frame("Statistics" = c("Min.", "1st Qu.", "Median", "Mean", "3rd Qu.", "Max.", "NA's"))  Trips <- data.frame("OD_Trips" = c(summary(od_ft_tt$trips)[[1]] %>% round(),                                     summary(od_ft_tt$trips)[[2]] %>% round(),                                      summary(od_ft_tt$trips)[[3]] %>% round(),                                     summary(od_ft_tt$trips)[[4]] %>% round(),                                     summary(od_ft_tt$trips)[[5]] %>% round(),                                    summary(od_ft_tt$trips)[[6]]%>% round(),                                    NA))  Travel_time <- data.frame("OD_Travel_time" = c(summary(od_ft_tt$travel_time)[[1]] %>% round(),                                                 summary(od_ft_tt$travel_time)[[2]] %>% round(),                                                  summary(od_ft_tt$travel_time)[[3]] %>% round(),                                                 summary(od_ft_tt$travel_time)[[4]] %>% round(),                                                 summary(od_ft_tt$travel_time)[[5]] %>% round(),                                                 summary(od_ft_tt$travel_time)[[6]] %>% round(),                                                  3507))   TAZ_Area <- data.frame("TAZ_Area" = c(summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[1]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[2]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[3]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[4]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[5]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[6]] %>% round(),                                        NA))  Workers <- data.frame("Workers" = c(summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[1]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[2]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[3]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[4]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[5]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[6]] %>% round(),                                      NA))  Jobs <- data.frame("Jobs" = c(summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[1]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[2]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[3]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[4]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[5]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[6]] %>% round(),                                NA))   desc_stats <- cbind(Statistics, Trips, Travel_time, TAZ_Area, Workers, Jobs)  #kable tabling  desc_stats %>%   kable(format = "latex",         align="lrrrrrr",         booktabs = T,         col.names = c(" ", "(#)", "(min)", "(km^2)", "(#)", "(#)"),         caption = "\\label{tab:TTS-16-desc-stats}Descriptive statistics of the trips, workers, and jobs for the traffic analysis zones (TAZ) from the TTS 2016 dataset along with estimated car origin-destination travel times.") %>%   add_header_above(c(" ", "Trips", "Car Travel Time", "Area", "Workers", "Jobs"), align = "r")%>%   kable_styling(full_width = "T",                  latex_options = c("scale_down"),                 position = "center")

title: Using this package
text: origin-destination information consists cross-tabulation people employed full-time place residence (origin) places employment GGH (destination) using GTA06 zoning system. number workers jobs equal; boundaries survey permeable, workers reside within boundaries travel outside boundaries counted workers within origin TAZ, jobs TAZ filled workers reside outside GGH boundaries unknown since surveyed. mismatch results total number workers 1.12 times larger number jobs (.e., 3,446,957 workers 3,081,900 jobs). 2016 TTS survey boundaries drawn minimize difference opportunities destination supply origins still equal . said, data offer perspective potential home-based trips places employment , number trips taken equal number workers GGH. Number workers (top) jobs (bottom) TAZ GGH area specified 2016 TTS. cumulative distribution number jobs workers per TAZ 2016 TTS data set. Light blue shaded ranges correspond cumulative proabilities number workers per TAZ larger jobs per TAZ. Figure  presents number workers jobs per TAZ. can observed spatial distribution jobs workers unequal, indicative jobs-housing imbalance, can impact accessibility region (Levine 1998). Workers concentrated TAZ within center GGH along south-east northern boarder GGH. center GGH corresponds Greater Toronto Area (GTA) densely populated area southern Ontario (Statistics Canada 2022). south east border GGH neighbours Lake Ontario delineated urban built boundary Ontario Growth Plan home highest density working population GGH (Ontario 2019; Auditor General Ontario 2021). northern GGH border corresponds Simcoe, Dufferin, Kawartha Lake, Peterborough regions home lower density worker population density population (Auditor General Ontario 2021). Conversely, spread jobs GGH lower number workers indicating population spatially dispersed jobs. can also seen bottom plot Figure  high medium-low concentrations jobs often present areas workers scale transformed. words, though higher number TAZ workers zones jobs (.e., 791 TAZ workers : 396 TAZ jobs) mean workers per TAZ higher mean jobs (.e., 916 workers : 819 jobs) number TAZ extreme number jobs highest lowest percentiles significantly higher number workers; see following cumulative probability distribution Figure  94th 100th percentile 0th 34th percentile jobs TAZ higher number workers TAZ. means ranges, TAZ higher number workers jobs, echoing even spatial distribution workers observed Figure .
code: tts_workers <- tm_shape(ggh_taz) +   tm_fill(col = "workers", title = "Full-time employed people", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tts_jobs <- tm_shape(ggh_taz) +   tm_fill(col = "jobs", title = "Full-time jobs", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tmap_arrange(tts_workers, tts_jobs) Number <- rbind(ggh_taz$jobs %>% data.frame(),                  ggh_taz$workers %>% data.frame()) Group <- rbind(rep("Jobs", each=length(ggh_taz$jobs)) %>% data.frame(),                 rep("Workers", each=length(ggh_taz$workers))%>% data.frame())  ecdf_data <- cbind(Number, Group) colnames(ecdf_data) <- c("Number", "Group")  rect1 <- data.frame(xmin=115, xmax=3055, ymin=-Inf, ymax=Inf)    ggplot(ecdf_data , aes(x=Number, col=Group)) +    # geom_segment(aes(x = 115, y = 0, xend = 115, yend = 0.34), col = "blue", linetype=2) +   # geom_segment(aes(x = 3055, y = 0, xend = 3055, yend = 0.94), col = "blue", linetype=2) +   geom_rect(data = rect1, aes(xmin=xmin, xmax=xmax, ymin=ymin, ymax=ymax), fill="lightblue", alpha=0.2, inherit.aes = FALSE) +   stat_ecdf() +    scale_x_continuous(trans='sqrt', breaks=c(115, 3055, 10000, 20000, 30000, 40000)) +    scale_y_continuous(breaks=c(0, 0.25,0.34, .50, .75,0.94, 1.00)) +   labs(x = "Opportunities per TAZ",        y = "Cumulative probability") +        scale_color_manual("Opportunities",                           values = c("Jobs" = "Black",                                     "Workers" = "Red"))+   scale_linetype_manual("Opportunities",values=c(0,1)) +   geom_point(aes(x = 115, y = 0.34), col = "blue")+   geom_point(aes(x=3055, y=0.94), col = "blue") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5),         legend.position = c(0.90,0.75),         axis.line = element_line(colour = "black"),         panel.border = element_blank())

title: Using this package
text: {TTS2016R} also includes travel time data home--work trip displayed Figure . travel time corresponds car commute calculated using R package {r5r} interpreted travel time work commute full-time employed people GGH. travel times calculated assuming following input parameters: maximum travel time less equal 180 mins (3 hrs) street network retrieved OpenStreetMaps GGH area. 3 hr threshold selected captures 99% trip taken (see travel times summarized Table ). important note travel times within data set calculated assuming car travel one departure time origins. assumptions completely realistic since know small proportion trips taken non-car modes travel time departures varies, however, possible data retrieval system obtain higher order tabulations allow us split data . Thus know trips made non-car modes exact departure times tables. Though modal split travel times can estimated methods (e.g., Allen Farber 2021; Higgins et al. 2021), simplicity, assume trips taken one-time departure car trip. Estimated total worker travel time (top) average worker travel time (bottom) TAZ GGH. can observed Figure , total travel time (min) resembles spatial trend distribution number employed people previous plot (Figure ). However, average travel time per trip TAZ presented, spatial distribution distinct plots presented far. can see areas around south-eastern border make Greater Toronto Hamilton Area (GTHA) (e.g., Hamilton, Halton, Peel, Toronto, York, Durham) Niagara Waterloo, average travel times moderately low. areas, travel times higher. Interestingly, even eastern areas (e.g., Peterborough) high employment high job concentration, average travel time higher within GTHA.
code: # remove all NA trips from dataset and set all 0min travel times to 0.1 min od_ft_tt  <- TTS2016R::od_ft_tt %>%    filter( !is.na(travel_time)) %>%    mutate(travel_time = ifelse(travel_time == 0, 0.1, travel_time))  all_tt <- od_ft_tt  %>%    dplyr::select(trips, travel_time)  all_tt <- all_tt[rep(seq_len(dim(all_tt)[1]), all_tt$trips), 2] #fitting impedance function gamma_ <- fitdistrplus::fitdist(data=all_tt, "gamma", method="mle", optim.method="Nelder-Mead") # transfer calibrated impedance function values to OD matrix od_ft_tt <- od_ft_tt %>%   mutate(f = dgamma(travel_time, gamma_$estimate["shape"], gamma_$estimate["rate"]))  #add the number of jobs and workers to the od_ft_tt matrix od_ft <- od_ft_tt %>% merge(ggh_taz %>% dplyr::select(GTA06, workers) %>% st_drop_geometry(),                    by.x = "Origin", by.y="GTA06", all.x = TRUE)  od_ft <- od_ft %>% merge(ggh_taz %>% dplyr::select(GTA06, jobs) %>% st_drop_geometry(),                    by.x = "Destination", by.y="GTA06", all.x = TRUE)   #calculate accessibility for workers from any origin to jobs in Toronto  GGH_c_accessibility <- od_ft %>%    mutate(GGH_A_ij = f * jobs) %>%   group_by(Origin) %>%   summarise(GGH_A_i = sum(GGH_A_ij, na.rm = T),             GGH_sum_tt_i = sum(travel_time),             GGH_tt_trips_i = mean(travel_time),             GGH_sum_f_i = sum(f),             GGH_f_trips_i = mean(f))  #Merge TO accessibly calculation to the ggh_taz: GGH_taz_acc <- ggh_taz %>% merge(GGH_c_accessibility, by.x=c("GTA06"), by.y=c("Origin"), all.x=T) tts_total_tt <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "GGH_sum_tt_i", title = "Total travel time\n per TAZ (min)", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tts_tt_per_trip <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "GGH_tt_trips_i", title = "Avg. travel time\n per TAZ (min)", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tmap_arrange(tts_total_tt, tts_tt_per_trip)

title: Using this package
text: Impedance functions useful understand mobility behavior part, instance, gravity models spatial interaction (Wilson 1971; Haynes Fotheringham 1985) accessibility analysis many applications (Hansen 1959; Levinson 1998; Talen Anselin 1998; Reggiani, Bucci, Russo 2011; Páez et al. 2013; Kuai Zhao 2017; Barboza et al. 2021). origin destination matrix cost matrix (.e., travel times) can used combination estimate impedance functions. impedance function \(f(\cdot)\) depends cost travel locations \(\) \(j\) \(c_{ij}\); usually monotonically decreasing function, although sometimes function can increase reflect patterns separation activities; instance, separation land uses means short commuting trips relatively rare. can sometimes also fluctuations due hierarchical patterns, travelers bypass opportunities favor distant destinations offer economies agglomeration. useful technique calibrate impedance function use trip length distribution (TLD) measured origin-destination data (Horbachov Svichynskyi 2018; Batista, Leclercq, Geroliminis 2019). TLD representation likelihood proportion trips taken specific travel cost. data set, assume cost travel time, impedance function maps low travel times higher proportions trips, high travel times mapped low proportion trips. GGH data presented, empirical TLD (.e., proportion trips taken vs. travel time minutes) fitted density distribution using maximum likelihood techniques Nelder-Mead method direct optimization available within fitdistrplus package (Delignette-Muller Dutang 2015). Based goodness--fit criteria diagnostics seen Figure  Figure , gamma distribution selected presented data. Empirical TTS 2016 home-based car trip length distribution (black) calibrated gamma distribution impedance function (red) associated Q-Q P-P plots resulting calibrated impedance function given following general form estimated ‘shape’ \(\alpha\) = 2.019, estimated ‘rate’ \(\beta\) = 0.094 , \(\Gamma(\alpha)\) defined Equation (). \[\begin{equation} \label{gamma-dist} \begin{array}{l}\  f(x, \alpha, \beta) = \frac {x^{\alpha-1}e^{-\frac{x}{\beta}}}{ \beta^{\alpha}\Gamma(\alpha)} \quad \text{} 0 \leq x \leq \infty\\ \Gamma(\alpha) =  \int_{0}^{\infty} x^{\alpha-1}e^{-x} \,dx\\ \end{array} \end{equation}\] Cullen frey graphy 2016 TTS calculated travel times.
code: knitr::include_graphics("images/impedance_function.png") # remove all NA trips from dataset and set all 0min travel times to 0.1min od_ft_tt  <- od_ft_tt %>% filter( !is.na(travel_time)) %>% mutate(travel_time = ifelse(travel_time == 0, 0.1, travel_time)) all_tt <- od_ft_tt  %>% dplyr::select(trips, travel_time) all_tt <- all_tt[rep(seq_len(dim(all_tt)[1]), all_tt$trips), 2] fitdistrplus::descdist(data=all_tt) #> summary statistics #> ------ #> min:  0.1   max:  179  #> median:  18  #> mean:  21.4344  #> estimated sd:  14.61254  #> estimated skewness:  1.703326  #> estimated kurtosis:  8.353363

title: Using this package
text: noted , impedance functions essential component accessibility analysis. Equation () shows accessibility \(A_i\) weighted sum opportunities can reached location \(\), given cost travel \(c_{ij}\). Summing opportunities neighborhood \(\) defined impedance function \(f(\cdot)\), provides estimates number opportunities can reached \(\) certain cost. \[\begin{equation} \label{eq:conventional-accessibility} A_i = \sum_{j=1}^JO_jf(c_{ij}) \end{equation}\] : \(\) accessibility. \(\) set origin locations. \(j\) set destination locations. \(O_j\) number opportunities location \(j\). opportunities activity add sort supply area; \(c_{ij}\) measure cost moving \(\) \(j\) \(f(\cdot)\) impedance function \(c_{ij}\). Accessibility (top) normalized accessibility (bottom) employment GGH area Accessibility property origin (.e., origin TAZ data), landscape opportunities (.e., TAZ destinations data), transportation infrastructure (.e., travel time table). Figure  presents accessibility estimates result impedance function calibrated preceding section. top plot, raw accessibility values, presents distinct radial trend majority TAZ around Toronto high accessibility values values gradually decrease TAZ Toronto’s boundary. Alternatively, bottom plot Figure  present worker-normalized accessibility values. words, accessibility value TAZ divided number workers TAZ. patterns plot similar Greater Toronto Area radial trend observed top plot less extreme (.e., smaller spread).
code: GGH_taz_acc <- GGH_taz_acc %>%   mutate(avg_A_per_W = GGH_A_i/workers) ## accessibility access_TTS_GGH <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "GGH_A_i", title = "Accessibility \n(A_i)", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  access_normalized_TTS_GGH <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "avg_A_per_W", title = "Average accessibility \nper worker", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tmap_arrange(access_TTS_GGH, access_normalized_TTS_GGH)

code: if (!require("remotes", character.only = TRUE)) {       install.packages("remotes")   } remotes::install_github("soukhova/TTS2016R",                         build_vignettes = TRUE) library(TTS2016R) library(tidyverse) library(ggplot2) library(kableExtra) library(patchwork) library(ggspatial) library(shadowtext) library(sf)

title: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada
text: 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area province Ontario, Canada (43.6°N 79.73°W) included; specifically location origins destinations defined Traffic Analysis Zones (TAZ), associated municipality boundaries, number jobs workers origin destination, trips origin destination morning home--work commute. Also included calculated travel times car (calculated via r5r) derived impedance function values corresponding cost travel based trip length distribution.  See plot spatial visualization number workers jobs within TAZ:  See .Rmd \data-raw folder additional details datasets compiled. See vignettes detailed examples using datasets comparing comparison conventional accessibility spatial availability measures.

title: TTS2016R: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada — TTS2016R-package
text: Maintainer: Anastasia Soukhov soukhoa@mcmaster.ca (ORCID) Authors: Antonio Paez paezha@mcmaster.ca (ORCID) Antonio Paez, School Earth, Environment Society, McMaster University paezha@mcmaster.ca Anastasia Soukhov, School Earth, Environment Society, McMaster University soukhoa@mcmaster.ca

title: ggh_pd — ggh_pd
text: object contains  municipality boundaries associated 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area.

title: ggh_pd — ggh_pd
text: dataframe containing 105 rows 4 variables; row represents unique planning region associated geo-referenced geometry. MUN name municipality /planning boundary. PD unique ID. REGION unique ID corresponding greater region PD part . REGION_name Names regions corresponding REGION ID. geometry sfc polygon geometry (boundaries).

title: ggh_pd — ggh_pd
text: "2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey" Data Management Group accessed Feburary 28th 2022.

title: ggh_taz — ggh_taz
text: object contains traffic analysis zones (TAZ) sourced 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area.

title: ggh_taz — ggh_taz
text: simple feature class (sf) polygon object containing 3764 rows 5 variables; row represents unique TAZ associated features. GTA06 Unique ID traffic analysis zone (TAZ). AREA Area TAZ units km^2. workers number full-time workers within TAZ. jobs number jobs within TAZd. geometry sfc polygon geometry (boundaries) TAZ.

title: ggh_taz — ggh_taz
text: "2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey" Data Management Group accessed November 14 2021.

title: od_ft_tt — od_ft_tt
text: object contains trips made origin (TAZ) destination (TAZ) full-time workers work destinations; sourced 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area. Also contained within calculated car travel time trip assuming 7:00 departure centroid TAZ Oct. 20 2021.

title: od_ft_tt — od_ft_tt
text: dataframe containing 103076 rows 4 variables; row represents unique trip origin TAZ destination TAZ associated features. Origin unique ID origin traffic analysis zone (TAZ). Destination unique ID destination traffic analysis zone (TAZ). Persons number people making trip. travel_time car travel time origin destination assuming 7:00 departure TAZ centroids Oct. 20 2021.

title: od_ft_tt — od_ft_tt
text: "2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey" Data Management Group accessed November 14 2021. Travel times calculated using r5r

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling rhs(lhs).

title: toy_od_table — toy_od_table
text: object contains hypothetical toy example Population, Jobs, Distance, Catchment Origin-Destination trip. Randomly generated.

title: toy_od_table — toy_od_table
text: dataframe containing 27 rows 7 variables; row represents unique trip "Population" "Employment Center" associated features. Origin unique ID "Population" 1 9 Destination unique ID "Employment Center" 1 3 Population population corresponding "Population" ID. Jobs number jobs corresponding "Employment Center" ID. distance distance origin destination (unitless). catchments binary code indicating origin-destination trip eligible (details can used within vignette). trips Randomly generated number trips made origin destination.

title: toy_sim_zones — toy_sim_zones
text: object contains geometries hypothetical toy example Origin Destination trip zones. Randomly generated.

title: toy_sim_zones — toy_sim_zones
text: simple feature class (sfc) multipolygon object containing 12 rows 5 variables; row represents unique "Population" "Employment Center" zone associated features. id unique ID "Population" (1 9) "Employment Center" (1 3) id_short short unique ID number population corresponding ID. type number jobs corresponding ID. geometry sfc polygon geometry (boundaries) ID.
